#load libraries
library(tidyverse)

Code
library(lubridate)
library(here)


here() starts at /cloud/project


Code
#load data
payments <- readRDS("trump_campaign_payments.rds")

title: Hannah Loder
text: Hi, I’m Hannah, and I am a journalist working to spread positivity through the work I produce. I am a student at George Washington University in the class of 2023 studying Journalism & Mass Communication and Spanish/Latin American Languages, Literatures & Cultures.

title: Hannah Loder
text:
Skills
Reporting and Writing
Audio and Video Editing
Graphic Design
Data Analysis

title: Portfolio
text: Explore my projects below. I use different mediums to share important stories impacting my community and the nation. I value the perspectives I am able to lift up in my reporting. I am grateful for the opportunity to meet new people and help tell their stories.

title: Portfolio
text:
Street Sense Media Articles
I wrote these articles during an editorial internship with Street Sense Media in the summer of 2022. I did the reporting, writing, worked with editors and took photos for the articles.

Tiny homes, big change: How DC can adapt tiny homes to fight homelessness 



The first Eden Village in Springfield has tiny homes facing each other. Photo by Hannah Loder




New number, same care: DC residents can now call 988 to receive support during a mental health crisis



The 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline is the new three-digit dialing code for behavioral health emergencies. Photo by Hannah Loder




One Journey Festival showcases what it means to be a refugee



Batalá Washington performs in the Unity Parade as children debut the welcome banner they made during the festival. Photo by Hannah Loder

title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
text:
Introduction
What data will you be working with?
A dataset of disbursements (payments and purchases) by the Donald J. Trump for President campaign committee during the 2020 election cycle. The included payments are from 2017 and 2018.
This data and examples were developed as part of the NYT Open training, which we’ve adapted from here. Note that the dataset has been alterted for instructional purposes, so doesn’t represent the original FEC data in its entirety.
In the environment tab in the upper right, click on the payments dataset to open the RStudio viewer to examine the data. You can also run the chunk below as well to bring up a slice of the data.


Code
head(payments)


# A tibble: 6 × 21
  committee…¹ elect…² repor…³ entit…⁴ entit…⁵ recip…⁶ recip…⁷ disbu…⁸ disburse…⁹
  <chr>         <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <date>    
1 DONALD J. …    2020    2018 ORG     ORGANI… AMERIC… VA      PLACED… 2018-10-23
2 DONALD J. …    2020    2018 ORG     ORGANI… ACE SP… LA      COLLAT… 2018-11-16
3 DONALD J. …    2020    2018 ORG     ORGANI… AMERIC… NJ      CREDIT… 2018-11-30
4 DONALD J. …    2020    2018 ORG     ORGANI… AMERIC… VA      PLACED… 2018-11-02
5 DONALD J. …    2020    2018 ORG     ORGANI… AMERIC… VA      ONLINE… 2018-12-19
6 DONALD J. …    2020    2018 ORG     ORGANI… AMERIC… NJ      CREDIT… 2018-12-31
# … with 12 more variables: disbursement_month <dbl>, disbursement_year <dbl>,
#   disbursement_amount <dbl>, election_type <chr>,
#   fec_election_type_desc <chr>, amendment_indicator_desc <chr>,
#   payee_last_name <chr>, payee_first_name <chr>, payee_middle_name <chr>,
#   recipient_city <chr>, disbursement_purpose_category <chr>, pdf_url <chr>,
#   and abbreviated variable names ¹​committee_name, ²​election_cycle,
#   ³​report_year, ⁴​entity_type, ⁵​entity_type_desc, ⁶​recipient_name, …

title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
text:
Before you begin
Take a moment to look at the various categories included for each disbursement.

Notice that there are several date-related fields:

FEC election cycle
report year
election type
disbursement date

There are a few fields about the recipient. Along with city and state, you have:

the recipient name
the payee’s first and last name (an individual who was paid for the “recipient”) and
the entity type (individual v. organization)

title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
text:
Initial Narrative Questions
Without doing any analysis yet, what are three questions you might try to answer using this dataset? Write your narrative answers in the spaces below.

Did Trump disburse more money to individuals or organizations?
Which states did he send the most money to? (including individuals and organizations)
During which election cycle did he spend the most money?

title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
text:
Coding Assignment Questions
Please write your R tidyverse code to help answer the questions below in the provided R chunks. You can make more than one chunk if you prefer.
Also, describe what you’re doing either in text out “in the open” above the chunk, or in comments (prefaced by #) in the R chunk itself.
You’ll need to use grouping, filtering, or a combination of both to find the answers. Remember that R is case-sensitive when you refer to any text values within the columns

How much was spent in the 2017 vs. 2018 reporting year?


Code
# I grouped by reporting year because 2017 and 2018 are the only reporting years,
# and I made a category for the sum to find the total spent. 

payments %>% 
  group_by(report_year) %>% 
  summarise(totalspent = sum(disbursement_amount))


# A tibble: 2 × 2
  report_year totalspent
        <dbl>      <dbl>
1        2017  16888149.
2        2018  37406905.


Tally the total overall disbursement amounts for each month (distinguishing between say, Oct. 2018 v. Oct. 2019). In which month was spending the highest?


Code
# I grouped by month and year and included the summarise function to find the total
# disbursement amount each month in each year. Then I arranged it to show the month 
# with the highest spending first. 

payments %>% 
  group_by(disbursement_month, disbursement_year) %>% 
  summarise(totalspent = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(totalspent))


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'disbursement_month'. You can override
using the `.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 24 × 3
# Groups:   disbursement_month [12]
   disbursement_month disbursement_year totalspent
                <dbl>             <dbl>      <dbl>
 1                 10              2018   9738568.
 2                 11              2018   7965133.
 3                 12              2018   3599035.
 4                  7              2018   2995762.
 5                  9              2018   2610151.
 6                  8              2018   2374412.
 7                  6              2017   2005105.
 8                  8              2017   1926848.
 9                  1              2017   1913251.
10                  2              2017   1728508.
# … with 14 more rows


Code
# Spending was the highest in October 2018. 


Which recipient (recipient_name) was paid the most in the 2020 election cycle?


Code
# I filtered by the 2020 election cycle and grouped by recipient name. Then I created
# a summarise function to tell me the total amount the recipient received. Then I arranged that
# to give the highest number first. 

payments %>% 
  filter(election_cycle == 2020) %>% 
  group_by(recipient_name) %>% 
  summarise(recipreceive = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(recipreceive))


# A tibble: 784 × 2
   recipient_name                       recipreceive
   <chr>                                       <dbl>
 1 AMERICAN MADE MEDIA CONSULTANTS, LLC     9772584.
 2 PARSCALE STRATEGY, LLC                   5739690.
 3 JONES DAY                                4390352.
 4 AMERICAN EXPRESS                         4174542.
 5 GILES-PARSCALE                           3535660.
 6 ACE SPECIALTIES                          3021340.
 7 ACE SPECIALTIES, LLC                     1029515.
 8 STRIPE                                   1009649.
 9 RED CURVE SOLUTIONS                       945623.
10 TRUMP TOWER COMMERCIAL LLC                890163.
# … with 774 more rows


Code
# American Made Media Consultants, LLC, received the most money in the 2020 election cycle.


Look at what this recipient was paid for. What service or good (see the “disbursement_description”) were they paid the most for?


Code
# I filtered by election cycle to only show the 2020 cycle, and I filtered by the 
# specific recipient I'm looking at. I grouped by the disbursement description and totaled
# up the amount received for that description. Then I arranged it in descending order to 
# show what they were paid most for. 

payments %>% 
  filter(election_cycle == 2020, recipient_name == "AMERICAN MADE MEDIA CONSULTANTS, LLC") %>% 
  group_by(disbursement_description) %>% 
  summarise(recipreceive = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(recipreceive))


# A tibble: 9 × 2
  disbursement_description                recipreceive
  <chr>                                          <dbl>
1 PLACED MEDIA                                4334158.
2 ONLINE ADVERTISING                          3650155.
3 ONLINE ADVERTISING & SUBSCRIPTIONS          1222606.
4 SUBSCRIPTIONS                                258126.
5 VIDEO PRODUCTION SERVICES                    166748.
6 DIGITAL CONSULTING/ONLINE ADVERTISING         75000 
7 DIGITAL CONSULTING & ONLINE ADVERTISING       30095 
8 DIGITAL CONSULTING                            20834.
9 RESEARCH CONSULTING                           14862.


Code
# American Made Media Consultants, LLC, was paid most for "placed media".


What’s the most common category overall (see “disbursement_description”) the campaign spent money on?


Code
# I grouped by disbursement description for all of the data. Then I used the summarise 
# function to count how many times that description showed up. Then I arranged it in 
# descending order to see what showed up the most.

payments %>% 
  group_by(disbursement_description) %>% 
  summarise(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 732 × 2
   disbursement_description                               count
   <chr>                                                  <int>
 1 MERCHANT FEES                                           1002
 2 PAYROLL                                                  439
 3 EVENT CONSULTING                                         312
 4 AMEX PMT [SB23.1401808]: TRAVEL: GROUND TRANSPORTATION   242
 5 AMEX PMT [SB23.4150]: TRAVEL: AIR                        212
 6 AMEX PMT [SB23.4150]: TRAVEL: GROUND TRANSPORTATION      203
 7 AMEX PMT [SB23.1405358]: TRAVEL: GROUND TRANSPORTATION   202
 8 AMEX PMT [SB23.4150]: TRAVEL: INSURANCE                  193
 9 AMEX PMT [SB23.4150]: TRAVEL: LODGING                    177
10 AMEX PMT [SB23.4148]: TRAVEL: GROUND TRANSPORTATION      170
# … with 722 more rows


Code
# The campaign spent money on "merchant fees" most often. 


Who were the 5 biggest recipients of campaign spending on “LEGAL CONSULTING”..?


Code
# I filtered by "legal consulting" and then I grouped by recipients. Then I used the sum 
# function to find out who received the most money. I arranged it in descending order
# and chose to only see the top 5 recipients. 

payments %>% 
  filter(disbursement_description == "LEGAL CONSULTING") %>% 
  group_by(recipient_name) %>% 
  summarise(totalamount = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(totalamount)) %>% 
  top_n(5)


Selecting by totalamount


# A tibble: 5 × 2
  recipient_name                             totalamount
  <chr>                                            <dbl>
1 JONES DAY                                     4390352.
2 LAROCCA HORNIK ROSEN GREENBERG & BLAHA LLP     404774.
3 KASOWITZ, BENSON, TORRESS & FRIEDMAN           322614.
4 THE LAW OFFICES OF ALAN S. FUTERFAS            287924 
5 MCDERMOTT WILL & EMERY                         276278.


Code
# The 5 biggest recipients are listed below when the code is run. 


Who are the top 5 individuals (vs. organization) were paid by the campaign committee?


Code
# I grouped by entity type and recipient name. Then I totaled up how much they were paid 
# and organized that in descending order. Then I chose to show the top 5 answers for 
# each entity. 

payments %>% 
  group_by(entity_type, recipient_name) %>% 
  summarise(amountpaid = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(amountpaid)) %>% 
  top_n(5)


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'entity_type'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.
Selecting by amountpaid


# A tibble: 10 × 3
# Groups:   entity_type [2]
   entity_type recipient_name                       amountpaid
   <chr>       <chr>                                     <dbl>
 1 ORG         AMERICAN MADE MEDIA CONSULTANTS, LLC   9772584.
 2 ORG         PARSCALE STRATEGY, LLC                 5739690.
 3 ORG         JONES DAY                              4390352.
 4 ORG         AMERICAN EXPRESS                       4174542.
 5 ORG         GILES-PARSCALE                         3535660.
 6 IND         GLASSNER, MICHAEL                       511280 
 7 IND         DOLLMAN, SEAN                           389541.
 8 IND         CENTINELLO, DARREN                      214934.
 9 IND         CARR, CHRISTOPHER                       160000 
10 IND         PENCE, JOHN                             104244.


Code
# The top 5 individuals and organizations are listed below when the code is run. 


For the indvidual who was paid the most, which payment category (disbursement_description) was the top one for him or her? And how much money were they paid in that category?


Code
# I filtered by Michael Glassner and grouped by the disbursement description. Then I 
# totaled the amount for the category, organized it in descending order and chose to
# only show the top answer. 

payments %>% 
  filter(recipient_name == "GLASSNER, MICHAEL") %>% 
  group_by(disbursement_description) %>% 
  summarise(amountcategory = sum(disbursement_amount)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(amountcategory)) %>% 
  top_n(1)


Selecting by amountcategory


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  disbursement_description amountcategory
  <chr>                             <dbl>
1 PAYROLL                          499000


Code
# The payment category was "payroll," and Michael was paid 499000 dollars.

title: Portfolio
text:
Planet Forward Projects
I created these audio and video projects using Adobe Audition, After Effects and Premiere Pro. They focus on environmental issues and are published on Planet Forward, a sustainability reporting outlet.

(In)vironmental Justice: Relationships to water in the Chesapeake Bay



A view of the Chesapeake Bay near Northeast, Maryland. Steve Adams/Unsplash
